articles.headline: Biden Walks a Cautious Line as He Opposes Defunding the Police
articles.snippet: As gruesome videos and energetic protests reshape public opinion about racial discrimination, Joe Biden tried to balance protesters’ calls for a law enforcement overhaul while not alienating moderate voters.
articles.abstract: As gruesome videos and energetic protests reshape public opinion about racial discrimination, Joe Biden tried to balance protesters’ calls for a law enforcement overhaul while not alienating moderate voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. staked out a careful position on Monday in support of a law enforcement overhaul but not defunding police departments, rebutting a new Republican attack line as he tries to harness growing activism against systemic racism while not alienating protesters or more moderate voters.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: ‘People Are Getting in Planes’: The Travel Business Is Picking Up
articles.snippet: After months of staying at home during the pandemic, Americans are heading to vacation destinations like Florida and national parks.
articles.abstract: After months of staying at home during the pandemic, Americans are heading to vacation destinations like Florida and national parks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest airlines are preparing for a limited rebound next month as more Americans book vacations in places like Florida and the mountains and national parks in the West.

articles.headline: Behind China’s Twitter Campaign, a Murky Supporting Chorus
articles.snippet: Swarms of accounts are amplifying Beijing’s brash new messaging as the country tries to shape the global narrative about the coronavirus and much else.
articles.abstract: Swarms of accounts are amplifying Beijing’s brash new messaging as the country tries to shape the global narrative about the coronavirus and much else.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Trump administration lashes out at China over a range of grievances, Beijing’s top diplomats and representatives are using the president’s favorite online megaphone — Twitter — to slap back with a pugnaciousness that is best described as Trumpian.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong, Aaron Krolik, Paul Mozur, Ronen Bergman and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Despite Recession, Stock Markets Turn Positive for the Year
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 climbed back above where it began the year on the same day that economists said the United States fell into a recession in February.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 climbed back above where it began the year on the same day that economists said the United States fell into a recession in February.
articles.lead_paragraph: And just like that, we’re back to where we started.

articles.headline: After Protests, Politicians Reconsider Police Budgets and Discipline
articles.snippet: Elected officials are exploring changes ranging from defunding police departments to requiring more accountability.
articles.abstract: Elected officials are exploring changes ranging from defunding police departments to requiring more accountability.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — In an abrupt change of course, the mayor of New York vowed to cut the budget of the nation’s largest police force. In Los Angeles, the mayor called for redirecting millions of dollars from policing after protesters gathered outside his home. And in Minneapolis, City Council members pledged to dismantle their police force and completely reinvent how public safety is handled. As tens of thousands of people have demonstrated against police violence over the past two weeks, calls have emerged in cities across the country for fundamental changes to American policing.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey, John Eligon and Farah Stockman

articles.headline: George Floyd, From ‘I Want to Touch the World’ to ‘I Can’t Breathe’
articles.snippet: Mr. Floyd had big plans for life nearly 30 years ago. His death in police custody is powering a movement against police brutality and racial injustice.
articles.abstract: Mr. Floyd had big plans for life nearly 30 years ago. His death in police custody is powering a movement against police brutality and racial injustice.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow the live updates on Seattle, Bubba Wallace, statues and the confederate flag.]
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: As Diners Flock to Delivery Apps, Restaurants Fear for Their Future
articles.snippet: While the apps say they are saving them in the pandemic, many restaurateurs say the opposite.
articles.abstract: While the apps say they are saving them in the pandemic, many restaurateurs say the opposite.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus lockdowns, Matt Majesky didn’t take much notice of the fees that Grubhub and Uber Eats charged him every time they processed an order for his restaurant, Pierogi Mountain.

articles.headline: A U.S. Secret Weapon in A.I.: Chinese Talent
articles.snippet: New research shows scientists educated in China help American firms and schools dominate the cutting-edge field. Now industry leaders worry that worsening political tensions will blunt that edge.
articles.abstract: New research shows scientists educated in China help American firms and schools dominate the cutting-edge field. Now industry leaders worry that worsening political tensions will blunt that edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Defense Department launched Project Maven, an effort to remake American military technology through artificial intelligence, it leaned on a team of about a dozen engineers working at Google. Many of them, according to two people familiar with the arrangement, were Chinese citizens.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Cade Metz

articles.headline: What It Looks Like Inside an Amazon Warehouse Now
articles.snippet: Amazon, which has been under fire on worker safety, invited us into one facility to show its response.
articles.abstract: Amazon, which has been under fire on worker safety, invited us into one facility to show its response.
articles.lead_paragraph: KENT, Wash. — After months of being embattled over its response to the coronavirus, Amazon is working to convince the public that its workplaces — specifically, the warehouses where it stores everything from toys to hand sanitizer — are safe during the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Ruth Fremson

articles.headline: Flying Was Once Routine. During the Pandemic, It’s a Feat.
articles.snippet: Masks, health checks, even worse food. Long-distance travel may never be the same.
articles.abstract: Masks, health checks, even worse food. Long-distance travel may never be the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Last week I stepped aboard the subway in Frankfurt for the first time since February, the start of a 4,000-mile trans-Atlantic journey to rejoin my wife after a three-month separation.
